<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_NetworkGetHostName:
```c
int32 OS_NetworkGetHostName(char *host_name, size_t name_len)
{
    int32 return_code;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(host_name);
    OS_CHECK_SIZE(name_len);

    /* delegate to low-level API */
    return_code = OS_NetworkGetHostName_Impl(host_name, name_len);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /* return an empty string on failure, just in case */
        host_name[0] = 0;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
host_name[0] = 0;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 violation. The statement host_name[0] = 0; does not call any <string.h> functions covered by Rule 21.17. Assuming OS_CHECK_POINTER(host_name) and OS_CHECK_SIZE(name_len) validate host_name != NULL and name_len > 0, the write is within bounds. A potential problem would occur only if OS_CHECK_SIZE does not ensure name_len > 0 (or is absent) — then host_name[0] = 0 would write out of bounds when name_len == 0.
